| Bacillus anthracis  | Chimpanzees            |
|                    | Gorilla                |
1. The parasites identified in this study are Bacillus anthracis, which is a bacterium that causes anthrax.2. The host species infected by these bacteria were chimpanzees and one gorilla. These animals were thought to have died of an anthrax-like disease.3. Here's the table with parasites in the first column and the infected hosts in the second column:
| Bacillus anthracis  | Chimpanzees, Gorilla |,60272

1. The study identified four species of acanthocephalans (Profilicollis altmani, P. kenti, P. major, Corynosoma enhydri) and three species of Digenea (Microphallus pirum, M. nicolli, Plenosoma minimum) in the gastrointestinal tracts of southern sea otters Enhydra lutris nereis.
2. The hosts infected by these parasites were southern sea otters (Enhydra lutris nereis).
3. Here is a table with the identified parasites and their respective host species:

| Parasite Species | Infected Host Species |
|------------------|-----------------------|
| Profilicollis altmani, P. kenti, P. major | Enhydra lutris nereis (Southern Sea Otters) |,60232

Title: Overwinter Fawn Mortality Associated With Hair Loss Syndrome in Columbian Black-tailed Deer Populations

Journal: Journal of Wildlife Diseases

Parasite/Pathogen Identification Table:

| Parasites | Host Species Infected |
| --- | --- |
| Sarcoptes scabiei (deer mite) | Columbian black-tailed deer (Odocoileus hemionus columbianus) |

Note: The study did not specifically identify other parasites or pathogens associated with hair loss syndrome in Columbian black-tailed deer populations. However, the presence of Sarcoptes scabiei (deer mite) was mentioned as a potential cause of hair loss syndrome.,60457
